title: Qutb Minar
summary: The Qutb Minar is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in the Mehrauli area of South Delhi, India. This minaret and victory tower is part of the Qutb complex, situated at the site of Delhi's oldest fortified city, Lal Kot. Its construction was initiated by Qutab-ud-din Aibak around 1199 to mark the beginning of Islamic rule, with subsequent levels added by various Delhi Sultanate dynasties, notably completed by Firuz Shah Tughlaq in 1368. Comprising 399 steps, it is a highly frequented heritage site known for its elaborate Islamic architecture, including inscriptions and geometric patterns. In recent years, it has served as a symbol for international relations, illuminated for occasions like Mexico's and Turkey's national days.
key_points: The Qutb Minar is a minaret and victory tower within the Qutb complex, a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Delhi, India.
Construction was initiated by Qutab-ud-din Aibak around 1199 to signify the beginning of Islamic rule in the region.
Successive dynasties of the Delhi Sultanate continued its construction, with Firuz Shah Tughlaq completing and rebuilding its top parts in 1368.
It features elaborate inscriptions and geometric patterns, similar to the Minaret of Jam in Afghanistan, and is one of Delhi's most-frequented heritage spots.
In recent years, the monument has been illuminated for special international diplomatic occasions, such as Mexico's Independence Day and the Republic of Turkey's anniversary.
timeline: c. 1190: Minaret of Jam in Afghanistan constructed (for comparison).
1199-1220: Qutab-ud-din Aibak initiated and largely oversaw the initial construction of the Qutb Minar, completing the first level.
1368: Firuz Shah Tughlaq rebuilt the top parts of the tower and added a cupola.
September 2023: Qutub Minar illuminated in Mexican flag colors for Mexico's 213th Independence Day.
October 30, 2023: Qutub Minar illuminated with the Turkish flag for the 100th anniversary of the Republic of Turkey.
important_figures: Qutab-ud-din Aibak (Initiated construction of Qutb Minar)
Firuz Shah Tughlaq (Completed and rebuilt parts of the tower)
Tomar Rajputs (Founders of Lal Kot, the site's original city)
Prithviraj Chauhan (Last Hindu ruler of Delhi before Ghurid conquest)
UNESCO (Designated as a World Heritage Site)
Embassy of Mexico in India (Acknowledged illumination)
Turkish Embassy in New Delhi (Acknowledged illumination)
applications: Tourism and heritage attraction for visitors.
Symbol for international diplomatic and cultural exchange events.
Site for historical and architectural research and study.
current_status: The Qutb Minar is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and remains one of the most-frequented heritage spots in Delhi. It is actively used for special international diplomatic occasions, being illuminated to commemorate foreign national days and anniversaries.
future_prospects: Future prospects include continued preservation as a significant historical and architectural marvel. It is likely to remain a major tourist attraction and continue to be utilized for diplomatic and cultural exchange events, strengthening international relations through its symbolic presence.
